# PJM Market Deep Dive

## What PJM Is and Why It's the Battleground

- **Coverage:** 13 states + DC, 65 million people
- **Capacity:** ~180 GW of installed generation
- **Northern Virginia:** The U.S. epicenter of data center development ("Data Center Alley")
- **Market type:** Competitive â€” generators must bid and win to dispatch

## Revenue Stream 1 â€” Energy Market (LMP)

| Period | Average PJM LMP |
|--------|----------------|
| H1 2024 | \$31.70/MWh |
| H1 2025 | **\$51.75/MWh** (+63%) |
| Case assumption | \$55â€“60/MWh |

: PJM Energy Market Prices {#tbl-lmp}

**Why LMP rose 63% in one year:**

$$
\text{Data centers added} \approx 3{,}000\text{ MW of new peak demand in PJM in 2025 alone}
$$
$$
12.3\text{ GW of capacity retired (mostly coal/gas)}
$$
$$
\Rightarrow \text{Net supply tightening: demand}{\uparrow} + \text{supply}{\downarrow} = \text{price}{\uparrow}
$$

## The Interconnection Crisis â€” A Critical Deal-Breaker

- PJM's interconnection queue has **170,000+ MW** of new generation requests (Jan 2026)
- Only **57 GW** have successfully completed the study process
- New projects face **1â€“2 year review timelines** just to enter the queue
- PJM received a **D- grade** from Advanced Energy United (2024)
- Dominion Zone data center load forecast: **20 GW by 2037** (up from 5.7 GW in 2022)

| Option | Interconnection Status | Time to First Power |
|--------|----------------------|---------------------|
| Build (new CCGT) | Must join 170,000 MW queue | **3â€“4 years** |
| Buy (existing) | Already interconnected â€” no queue | **Immediate** |
| Partner (co-location) | Behind-the-meter â€” bypasses queue | **Immediate** |

## Path A â€” BUILD (New 550 MW CCGT) {#sec-build}

**What it is:** Construct a brand-new combined-cycle gas turbine plant from scratch.

### Financial Snapshot

| Metric | Value | How Calculated |
|--------|-------|----------------|
| Total Capex | \$687.5M | 550,000 kW Ã— \$1,250/kW |
| Annual Generation | 3,373 GWh | 550 MW Ã— 0.70 Ã— 8,760 hrs |
| Fuel Cost/MWh | \$23.06 | (6,150/1,000,000) Ã— \$3.75 Ã— 1,000 |
| Carbon Cost/MWh | \$7.20 | (720/2,000) Ã— \$20/ton |
| Total Op Cost/MWh | \$35.38 | Fuel + Var O&M + Fixed O&M + Carbon |
| LCOE | **\$55.65/MWh** | Capital recovery + all operating costs |
| Merchant Margin | +\$4.35/MWh | \$60 market price âˆ’ \$55.65 LCOE |
| Annual EBITDA | **~\$115M** | Revenue âˆ’ Operating Costs |
| Avg Annual FCF | **\$47.4M** | From financial model |
| NPV @ 7.68% | **âˆ’\$133.6M** | Slightly value-destructive |
| IRR | ~7.5% | Just below WACC of 7.68% |
| Payback Period | 7â€“8 years | |

: Build Gas â€” Financial Snapshot {#tbl-build-financials}

**Interest carry during 24-month construction:**

$$
\text{Debt portion} = \$687.5\text{M} \times 60\% = \$412.5\text{M}
$$
$$
\text{Annual interest} = \$412.5\text{M} \times 8\% = \$33\text{M/year}
$$
$$
\text{24-month carry} = \$33\text{M} \times 2 = \$66\text{M in interest before first MWh}
$$

### Pros & Cons

**Advantages:**

- Modern, efficient technology (6,150 Btu/kWh heat rate â€” best-in-class)
- 20-year economic life â€” long runway
- You control siting â€” can locate near NoVA data center hubs
- Dispatchable / flexible â€” valuable as grid backup
- Capacity market eligible

**Disadvantages:**

- 24-month construction + 1â€“2 yr interconnection queue â†’ **3â€“4 years with zero revenue**
- Full merchant risk â€” revenue fluctuates daily with PJM LMP
- Gas price exposure: if gas rises to \$5/MMBtu (Morgan Stanley 2026), fuel cost rises **+33%**
- Carbon exposure at 720 lb/MWh: at \$100/ton â†’ **\$121.4M/year**
- ESG misalignment â€” all major hyperscalers committed to 100% carbon-free by 2030â€“2040
- **Negative NPV of âˆ’\$133.6M** at base case pricing

: Partner Nuclear â€” Financial Snapshot {#tbl-partner-financials}

> **Critical note on NPV:** The base-case NPV of âˆ’\$1,467M assumes \$60/MWh PPA pricing. This is **25â€“40% below actual market deals** (Microsoftâ€“Constellation: ~\$100/MWh; Metaâ€“Constellation: \$85â€“90/MWh). At \$85/MWh â€” still below the Microsoft deal â€” NPV improves by ~\$1.47B to near break-even. At \$100/MWh, NPV is strongly positive at ~+\$1.5B.

**NPV improvement from \$60 â†’ \$85/MWh PPA:**

$$
\text{Additional revenue/MWh} = \$85 - \$60 = \$25\text{/MWh}
$$
$$
\text{Annual additional revenue} = \$25 \times 6{,}447{,}000\text{ MWh} = \$161.2\text{M/year}
$$
$$
\text{PV annuity factor (17yr @ 7.68\%)} = 9.12
$$
$$
\text{Additional NPV} = \$161.2\text{M} \times 9.12 \approx +\$1.47\text{B}
$$

| Microsoftâ€“Constellation (Three Mile Island) | **~\$100/MWh** | 20 years |
| Metaâ€“Constellation (Clinton plant) | **\$85â€“90/MWh** | 20 years |
| Case model base assumption | \$60/MWh | Conservative |

```{python}
#| label: fig-nuclear-npv-sensitivity
```

# Weighted Scoring & Ranking

## Evaluation Framework

| Criterion | Weight | Rationale |
|-----------|:------:|-----------|
| Risk-Adjusted Return | 30% | FCF growth, NPV, payback |
| Scalability / Replicability | 20% | Can this be repeated? |
| Trend Alignment | 25% | AI/DC demand, ESG, hyperscaler fit |
| Regulatory / Competitive Risk | 25% | Carbon, interconnection, market risk |

## Scores

| Criterion | Build | Buy | Partner | Weight |
|-----------|:-----:|:---:|:-------:|:------:|
| Risk-Adjusted Return | 2 | 4 | 3* | 30% |
| Scalability | 3 | 2 | 5 | 20% |
| Trend Alignment | 2 | 2 | 5 | 25% |
| Regulatory/Competitive Risk | 2 | 3 | 4 | 25% |
| **Weighted Score** | **2.25** | **2.80** | **4.25** | |

*Partner scores 3 on risk-adjusted return at base pricing, but **5 at real-world PPA pricing** (\$85â€“100/MWh).

**Ranking: Partner > Buy > Build**

```{python}
#| label: fig-scoring
#| fig-cap: "Weighted Scoring Radar â€” Build vs Buy vs Partner"
```

## Q1: How Much to Invest? In What? In What Proportions?

**Answer: \$3.45B total (Recommended Hybrid: Nuclear Partnership + Gas Acquisition)**

| Component | Amount | % of Total | Rationale |
|-----------|-------:|:---------:|-----------|
| Nuclear plant acquisition | \$3,000M | 87% | Existing plant; no construction risk |
| Existing gas plant acquisition | \$450M | 13% | Immediate cash flow; bridge financing |
| **Total** | **\$3,450M** | **100%** | |

|---|---:|:---:|

| Refurbishment / upgrades | \$300M | 10% |
| Engineering & due diligence | \$100M | 3% |
| Site infrastructure | \$100M | 3% |

**Why \$3,000M for nuclear:**

$$
\text{Nuclear: } \$3{,}000\text{M} \div 800{,}000\text{ kW} = \$3{,}750\text{/kW}
$$

*(Vistraâ€“Energy Harbor benchmark: \$3.4B Ã· 6,400 MW = \$531/kW. Our premium reflects co-location value + PPA structure.)*

## Q2: How Will You Finance It?

**Answer: 60% Debt / 40% Equity (per case assumptions), with partner co-funding reducing equity need**

| Source | Amount (on \$3.45B) | Cost | Notes |
|--------|-------------------:|:----:|-------|
| Senior Secured Debt | \$1,725M (50%) | 8% | Contracted PPA makes this bankable |
| Equity (Share Issuance) | \$1,035M (30%) | 12% | ~5% dilution at \$20B market cap |
| Partner Co-Funding | \$690M (20%) | Shared economics | Hyperscaler co-invests |
| Existing Cash | \$260M (available) | Internal | Partially depletes cash reserve |

**WACC Calculation:**

$$
\text{WACC} = (D\% \times k_d \times (1-T)) + (E\% \times k_e)
$$
$$
= (0.60 \times 0.08 \times 0.60) + (0.40 \times 0.12)
$$
$$
= 0.0288 + 0.0480 = \mathbf{7.68\%}
$$

**Annual interest expense (nuclear):**

$$
\text{Debt} = \$3{,}000\text{M} \times 60\% = \$1{,}800\text{M}
$$
$$
\text{Annual interest} = \$1{,}800\text{M} \times 8\% = \$144\text{M/year}
$$
$$
\text{Tax shield} = \$144\text{M} \times 40\% = \$57.6\text{M/year saved}
$$

**Dilution from equity raise:**

$$
\text{New shares} = \frac{\$1{,}035\text{M}}{\$444/\text{share}} \approx 2.33\text{M shares}
$$
$$
\text{Dilution} = \frac{2.33\text{M}}{47.33\text{M}} \approx 4.9\%
$$

$$
\text{Build break-even} = \frac{\$139.3\text{M EBITDA (pre-carbon)}}{1{,}214{,}136\text{ tons}} = \mathbf{\$114.7\text{/ton}}
$$
$$
\text{Buy break-even} = \frac{\$133.3\text{M EBITDA (pre-carbon)}}{1{,}264{,}725\text{ tons}} = \mathbf{\$105.4\text{/ton}}
$$

*At ~\$105â€“115/ton carbon price, gas plants generate zero profit. Nuclear is immune to this risk entirely.*

# Industry Facts â€” Deal Breakers

These are the facts that win or lose the case in front of judges. Each directly supports the Partner recommendation.

## Fact 1 â€” PJM Interconnection Queue = 170,000 MW Backlog

- PJM has processed **170,000+ MW** of new generation requests (Jan 2026)
- Only **57 GW** signed interconnection agreements and can build
- New projects face **1â€“2 year review timelines** to enter the queue
- PJM received a **D- grade** (Advanced Energy United, 2024)

> *Impact: Building a new gas plant = waiting 3â€“4 years before generating a single MWh. Behind-the-meter co-location bypasses this entirely.*

## Fact 2 â€” Dominion Zone Data Center Load = 20 GW by 2037

- 2022 forecast: 5.7 GW â†’ 2025 forecast: **20 GW by 2037** (3.5Ã— increase)
- PJM's 5-year load growth forecast nearly doubled: 2.6% â†’ **4.7%** in one year

## Fact 3 â€” Nuclear Capacity Factor = 90.96% (3-Year Average)

- U.S. nuclear fleet average CF: **90.96%** (ANS, 2022â€“2024 median)
- 95%+ of U.S. nuclear units expected to receive **80-year operating licenses**
- 73%+ of nuclear sites planning **power uprates** (+5 GW of carbon-free capacity)

## Fact 4 â€” Real Nuclear PPA Prices = \$85â€“100/MWh (Not \$60)

- Microsoftâ€“Constellation (TMI): **~\$100/MWh**, 20-year term
- Metaâ€“Constellation (Clinton): **\$85â€“90/MWh**, 20-year term
- Case model: \$60/MWh â€” **25â€“40% below market**

## Fact 5 â€” PJM Capacity Prices Hit Record \$329/MW-day in 2026/2027

## Fact 6 â€” EPA Rolled Back Carbon Rules in 2025â€“2026

- EPA proposed repealing all GHG emissions standards (June 2025)
- EPA rescinded the 2009 Greenhouse Gas Endangerment Finding (Feb 2026)

**Nuanced impact:** Near-term carbon risk is reduced *for gas plants*, but:

1. Legal challenges expected â€” rules could be reinstated
2. State-level carbon pricing (RGGI, California) still applies in some markets
3. Hyperscaler sustainability commitments are *corporate policy* â€” they don't change with EPA rules
4. Long-term 20-year gas investments still face risk from future administrations

## Fact 7 â€” U.S. Government Targets Quadrupling Nuclear Capacity by 2050

- IEA: Nuclear generation reached record levels in 2025
